title: Agrobacterium-Mediated Transformation of Setaria viridis, a Model System for Cereals and Bioenergy Crops
procedures:
In this first section, we describe the protocol to generate callus starting from dry mature seeds. This method utilizes dehusked seeds, followed by sterilization and plating in callus-inducing medium to generate high-quality callus. The resulting callus is amenable to Agrobacterium-mediated transformation when implemented as described below. Materials S. viridis (ME034V-1) seeds Note that ME034V-1 = ME034V. Source: https://npgsweb.arsgrin.gov/gringlobal/accessiondetail?id=1918592[href=https://npgsweb.arsgrin.gov/gringlobal/accessiondetail?id=1918592]. 6% (v/v) bleach (Clorox) 1% (v/v) Tween 20 (Sigma, cat. no. P1379) Callus induction medium (CIM) plates (see recipe[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-rec-0002]) Seed dehusking device (Fig. 2B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0002]) The seed dehusking device used in this work was made using wooden pieces and fine-rib corrugated rubber matting assembled in the shape of a float trowel (similar to the tool commonly used to level and smooth concrete) and a base tray. The bottom surface of the float and the base tray inner surface are lined with a corrugated plastic sheet with a ribbed side facing outwards. Rubber matting used in the device was purchased from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01DCR5JB2/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&th=1[href=http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01DCR5JB2/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&th=1]). Alternatively, a method described by Van Eck and Swartwood (2015)[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-bib-0019] can be used to dehusk the seeds. 50-ml conical tube (Falcon, cat. no. 352070) Fine-tip forceps Vertical rotating mixer (BenchTop Lab Systems, cat. no. VM-80) Rocking platform Whatman filter paper (Whatman, cat. no. 1001-085) Laminar flow hood Plastic wrap (we routinely use plastic wrap from GLAD to wrap Petri plates containing plant tissue during various stages of transformation) or Micropore tape (3M Company) Plant growth chambers with following conditions: 24°C dark 24°C, 16-hr photoperiod, 60 μ/m2/s light Stereomicroscope

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/b05c1979-ebb1-461c-98f1-01ff358d84eb/cpz1127-fig-0002-m.jpg

Figure 2

Dehusking of seed husks from mature Setaria viridis (ME034V-1) seeds. (A) Seeds with intact husks. (B) Device for seed dehusking. (C) Dehusked seeds after removal of chaff. Inset shows close-up view of dehusked seeds. (D) Dehusked seeds (embryo-side up is on the left and endosperm-side up is on the right) under the stereo microscope. Initiation of callus from S. viridis ME034V-1 seeds 1. Remove seed coats from 2-3 g of dry seeds (dehusk the seeds; Fig. 2A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0002]). We use a homemade device shown in Figure 2B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0002] for the removal of the seed coat. Avoid applying too much pressure on the seeds, as it could damage the embryos. Remove chaff and seeds that retain their seed coat (Fig. 2C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0002] and 2D[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0002]). 2. Sterilize the dehusked seeds in a 50-ml conical tube filled with 40 ml of sterilization solution made with 10% bleach plus 0.1% Tween-20 for 10 min on rotating mixer at 30 rpm (Fig. 3A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0003]).

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/c3f830e9-07eb-4c8f-92a9-94849a7893c1/cpz1127-fig-0003-m.jpg

Figure 3 Various steps of seed sterilization. (A) Treatment of dehusked seeds with bleach solution. (B) Sterilized seeds in water. (C) Sterilized seeds poured on to Whatman filter paper. (D) Sterilized seeds under stereomicroscope. 3. Rinse seeds five times with sterile deionized water, gently rocking the tube for 1-2 min during each rinse step (Fig. 3B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0003]). 4. After the completion of the final rinsing step, remove the excess water and transfer the sterilized seeds on top of two to three pieces of dry, sterile Whatman paper (Fig. 3C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0003] and 3D[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0003]). Allow seeds to dry in a laminar flow hood for 20-30 min.

5. Plate out ∼25 evenly spaced seeds (Fig. 4A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0004]) with the intact embryo facing upwards onto each plate containing CIM medium (Fig. 4B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0004]). This orientation is important for the development of high-quality, regenerable callus compared to seeds with the embryo side plated touching the medium surface (Fig. 4C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0004]). Wrap plates with plastic wrap or Micropore tape and place plates in a growth chamber maintained at 24°C with a photoperiod of 16 hr for 1 week (Fig. 5A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0005]) followed by 4-5 weeks incubation in the dark at 24°C.

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/c5c88111-43b5-4701-a7e4-782dad1430b7/cpz1127-fig-0004-m.jpg

Figure 4 Sterilized seeds plated on CIM medium to initiate callus. (A) Seeds on CIM medium. (B) Correct orientation of seeds embryo-side up on CIM medium surface. (C) Wrong orientation of seeds (endosperm-side up) on CIM medium surface.

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/01e7069c-aa77-45ec-a21c-8512345cc17f/cpz1127-fig-0005-m.jpg

Figure 5 Various stages of callus generation. (A) Callus after 1-week incubation in light. (B) Callus after 6 weeks in dark. (C) Callus sub-cultured on CIM medium plate. (D) High-quality callus generated from the seeds. Yellow arrows represent the location of high-quality callus selected for sub-culturing and used for transformation. (E) Representative example of gelatinous/watery callus—not suitable for transformation. (F) Close-up view of high-quality sub-cultured callus. 6. Remove any leaves, roots, and gelatinous or dead tissue from the callus (Fig. 5E[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0005]) and sub-culture calli (Fig. 5B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0005] and 5D[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0005]) onto freshly prepared CIM (Fig. 5C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0005]). Incubate newly sub-cultured calli in the dark at 24°C for 1 week (Fig. 5C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0005] and 5F[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0005]) prior to transformation with Agrobacterium (Basic Protocol 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-prot-0002]). Callus quality is the most important factor in achieving high and reproducible transformation frequencies. When possible, use the youngest available material that has reached a size of 2-4 mm. Subsequent sub-culturing of poor-quality callus onto new medium results in a significant decline in the transformation efficiency.—

The following protocol describes the generation of transgenic plants via A. tumefaciens-mediated transformation using callus derived from mature seeds, as described in Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-prot-0001]. This basic protocol is divided into three steps: (i) preparation of Agrobacterium for transformation, (ii) inoculation and co-culture of explants derived from Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-prot-0001] with Agrobacterium strain AGL1 containing binary plasmid, and (iii) selection and regeneration of plants. Materials A. tumefaciens (AGL1) containing a binary vector that contains a selectable marker gene cassette comprising a ubiquitin promoter driving hygromycin phosphotransferase (hyg) e.g., binary vector pANIC10A (Mann et al., 2012[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-bib-0009]; pANIC10 vector obtained from Addgene); see Support Protocol[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-prot-0004] for culture and preparation LB plates containing appropriate antibiotics (see recipe[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-rec-0005]) Liquid CIM (liquid callus induction medium; see recipe[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-rec-0004]) 200 mM acetosyringone (Solution F; see recipe[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-rec-0008] for Stock solutions) Callus generated from mature seeds of S. viridis (ME034V-1) (see Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-prot-0001]) Co-culture medium plates (see recipe[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-rec-0001]) Plant regeneration medium plates (see recipe[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-rec-0006]) Plant rooting medium plates (see recipe[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-rec-0007]) Growth chamber with following condition: 24°C light/dark photoperiod (16 hr/8 hr) 21°C dark 50-ml conical tubes (Falcon, cat. no. 352070) Disposable loops (VWR, cat. no. 30002-090) Spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific, GENESYS 30) Sterile filter paper, 85 mm diameter (Whatman, cat. no. 1001-085) Petri plates, 20 × 100 mm (VWR, cat. no. 25384-342) Aluminum foil Solo cups, 8 oz, 236 ml; Solo Cup Company, cat. no. SD8) or Magenta boxes Preparation of Agrobacterium for transformation 1. Three days prior to the initiation of transformation, streak a lawn of Agrobacterium from a “master plate” (see Support Protocol[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-prot-0004]) onto LB plates containing the appropriate selection agents (e.g., carbenicillin and kanamycin for A. tumefaciens AGL1 containing pANIC10A binary vector). Incubate plate at 22°C for 2 days (Fig. 6A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0006]).

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/aa909628-cd87-47d5-9640-4e5448abbe75/cpz1127-fig-0006-m.jpg

Figure 6

Infection and co-culture. (A) Preparation of Agrobacterium culture for infection. Inset shows the loop-full amount of Agrobacteria scooped from the culture plate. (B) Close-up of Agrobacterium suspension in inoculation medium ready for infection of callus (inset shows Agrobacterium suspension culture in 50-ml conical tube). (C) Close-up view of inoculation of callus with Agrobacterium suspension culture (inset shows infection in 50-ml conical tube). (D) Infected callus transferred onto the Whatman paper placed on top of the medium plate. (E) Infected callus pieces spread out on the filter paper for co-cultivation.
2. Take 2-3 loops of Agrobacterium lawn (using a 1-μl loop) and inoculate into a 50-ml conical tube containing 10 ml of liquid CIM medium supplemented with 200 μM acetosyringone. Gently shake the tube until all Agrobacteria have evenly dispersed in the liquid medium to form a homogeneous suspension (Fig. 6B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0006]).
3. Measure OD600 and adjust to 0.25-0.4 with liquid CIM supplemented with 200 μM acetosyringone (Fig. 6B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0006]).
OD600 measurement can vary dependent on the type of instrument. We use GENESYS 30 spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher) for optical density measurements.
Inoculation of explants and co-culture
4. Transfer ∼100 calli from 1-week-old sub-cultured callus (step 6 of Basic Protocol 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-prot-0001]) into a sterile 50-ml conical tube.
5. Add liquid CIM containing Agrobacterium suspension (from step 3) so that the callus is completely submerged in the Agrobacterium suspension solution (Fig. 6C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0006]).
6. Vortex gently for 10 s and incubate for 5 min.
7. Pour calli and Agrobacterium solution onto a stack of 2-3 sterile sheets of filter paper placed inside an empty Petri plate. Swirl plate until solution has soaked into the filter paper (Fig. 6D[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0006]).

8. Transfer 100 calli per petri plate from step 7 directly onto a sterile sheet of filter paper that is placed on top of co-culture medium in a Petri plate (Fig. 6E[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0006]). 9. Wrap plates with aluminum foil and incubate in dark for 3 days at 22°C for co-culture. Selection and regeneration of plants 10. Transfer callus to CIM Selection 60 medium plates (CIM Selection 60-I; see Fig. 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0001]). Place ∼20 pieces of calli per plate and incubate in dark for 2 weeks at 24°C (Fig. 7A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0007] and 7D[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0007]).

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/5ff1326a-bb22-4718-8358-8757bf7115fc/cpz1127-fig-0007-m.jpg

Figure 7 Selection of transformed callus on hygromycin-containing CIM medium, and regeneration. (A) Callus on CIM Selection-I medium plate. (B) Callus on CIM Selection-II. (C) Regeneration from hygromycin-resistant callus. (D) Close-up of callus after 2 weeks on CIM Selection-I. (E) Close-up of callus after 2 weeks on CIM Selection-II. 11. Subculture callus to fresh CIM Selection 60 medium plates (CIM Selection 60-II; see Fig. 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0001]). Transfer ∼14 pieces per plate and incubate in dark for 2 weeks at 24°C in the dark (Fig. 7B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0007] and 7E[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0007]). 12. Transfer callus to plant regeneration medium (Regeneration-I; see Fig. 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0001]). Transfer ∼12 callus pieces per fresh regeneration medium plate and incubate at 24°C under a 16-hr photoperiod for 2 weeks. Repeat for additional 2 weeks under same conditions with ∼ 8 callus pieces per medium plate (Regeneration-II; see Fig. 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0001]). 13. Subculture callus onto the fresh plant rooting medium plates (Rooting; see Fig. 1[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0001]) containing the appropriate selection. Transfer 4 callus pieces per plate and incubate at 24°C under a 16-hr photoperiod for 1-2 weeks until shoots have developed (Fig. 7C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0007] and 7F[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0007]).

14. Once shoots have developed, transfer ∼10 mm tall shoots to the rooting medium plates, typically four independent events/plantlets per plate, with a Solo Cup lid (Fig. 8A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0008]-8C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0008]), and incubate at 24°C under a 16-hr photoperiod for 1-2 weeks until the plantlet is big enough and formed robust roots system (Fig. 8D[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0008]).

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/f01b916c-bdc5-4f1c-a0a4-89810b79c283/cpz1127-fig-0008-m.jpg

Figure 8 Regenerated plants in rooting medium. (A) Plantlets in rooting medium with Solo cup lids. (B) Close-up view of plants from top view without solo cup lid. (C) Close-up view of roots from the bottom-side of the medium plate. (D) Plantlets ready for transplantation in soil. 15. When the shoots have well established primary and lateral root systems (Fig. 8C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0008]), transplant them into soil (Basic Protocol 3[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-prot-0003]).

The shoots from Basic Protocol 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-prot-0002] that have well-developed root systems are transferred to soil for further growth and seed collection. The method outlined below offers the highest survivability potential for putative transgenic plantlets under greenhouse conditions. Routine monitoring and inspection of plantlets is advisable to identify any issues and implement corrective measures in a timely manner to maintain healthy plant growth for optimal seed collection. Materials S. viridis (accession: ME034V-1) plantlets from Basic Protocol 2[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-prot-0002] Potting soil (Jolly Gardener Products, Inc., Jolly Gardener Potting Soil) Reverse osmosis (RO) water (U.S. Filter, cat. no. ROSLV21602) Fertilizer: Jack's Professional 20-20-20 General Purpose (JR Peters, Inc., cat. no. 77010) Plastic holding trays with holes (Hummert International, Flat T.O. Plastics Standard 1020 Open W/Holes, cat. no. item no. 11300000; see Fig. 9[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0009]) Flat 1801 Deep individually perforated inserts (Hummert International, Insert T.O. Plastics 1801 Standard, cat. no. 11075000; see Fig. 9[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0009]) Spray bottle Humi-Dome, Clear Plastic (Hummert International, cat. no. 14385100) Greenhouse, 31°C/16 hr light and 22°C/8 hr dark, 50% humidity, lighting: 250 µmol Optional: Total dissolved solids (TDS) meter (Hanna Instruments, cat. no. HI 9813 - 5) Perforated 6-in × 28-in clear plastic bags (Penn Jersey Paper Company, cat. no. 361001) 1/4-in. × 4-in. 1/4-in. × 7-in. twist ties (T and T Industries Inc, cat. no. 35-925-41-3000 and 35-025-07-3000) Plastic stakes (for labeling of transgenic plants) Scissors Weighing boats Coin envelope (Uline, cat. no. S-7798)

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/f45a9c79-6293-47b8-9f85-34b9e4182b1f/cpz1127-fig-0009-m.jpg

Figure 9 Preparation of soil trays for the transplantation. (A-D) Insert and holding trays setup. (B) Tray with soil. (C) Soil with holes made by fingers and event identifying labels. Transplantation of plantlets from tissue culture medium plate to soil 1. Prepare trays by placing 1801 deep inserts into 1020 flats with holes (Fig. 9A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0009]-D[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0009]).

2. Fill 1801 cells with Jolly Gardener potting soil. Do not pack or compact soil. Use RO water to thoroughly saturate the soil (Fig. 9E[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0009]). 3. Create a dimple in the soil for each cell with your finger for the easy placement of the plantlets (Fig. 9F[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0009]). 4. Remove plantlets individually from the Petri dish by separating them gently from the callus at the juncture between the shoot and the roots (Fig. 10[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0010]). Remove all medium that is still attached to the roots by rinsing with RO water before placing the plantlet into the designated cell. Cover the roots with soil by gently tapping the soil around the root mass and stem base. Do not compress the soil excessively, as this can lead to root and plant stunting (Fig. 10[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0010]).

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/3261d7a2-ffcf-4026-b110-654b88f86f9e/cpz1127-fig-0010-m.jpg

Figure 10 Transplantation of plantlets from tissue culture medium to soil. 5. Repeat steps 3 and 4 until all plantlets have been transplanted to soil. 6. Place flats with plantlets in the greenhouse with a Humi-Dome and spray with RO water 2-3 times daily for approximately 3 days after which the Humi-Dome is removed. 7. Supplement bottom water as needed 1-2 times per week with Jack's 20-20-20 fertilizer mixed at a concentration of 200 ppm. It takes approximately 2-3 weeks for plants to begin to develop inflorescence. Optionally, a total dissolved solids (TDS) meter can be used to test and confirm the ppm of the solutes in the water. 8. Bag plants with maturing inflorescence, which have approximately ¼ of their seeds dark in color, using perforated clear plastic bags by gently pulling the bag over the plant to the base where it can then be tied off using a 4-in. twist-tie. Secure the plants around the stake using 7-in. twist-ties (6 plants per stake).

Staking will keep plants erect and allow for better airflow as plants mature (Figs. 11[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0011] and 12[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0012]).

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/6099bcdc-419f-43a3-9193-31dcdc36bad9/cpz1127-fig-0011-m.jpg

Figure 11 Growth of transgenic plants in soil. Inset shows the inflorescence stage ready for the bagging.

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/a24df214-77a8-4c2f-bf1b-7957a6ccc0ca/cpz1127-fig-0012-m.jpg

Figure 12 Bagging of inflorescence and drying of plantlets. (A) Bagging of the inflorescence. Yellow arrow represents the location ideal to tie the bag to minimize the loss of seeds and health of the plants. (B) Close-up of inflorescence: representative example of the stage of inflorescence before stopping the irrigation and starting the plant dry-out process. 9. Continue monitoring plants for signs of fungus, pests, and condensation near the panicle and address those accordingly. If condensation is observed inside bags, reduce watering frequency, as this can lead to fungus or other plant health issues causing poor seed development or premature plant death and consequent loss of transgenic lines). 10. Once approximately 50% of the seeds on the panicle have matured and turned darker in color, stop watering to allow plants to completely dry down prior to harvest (Fig. 12[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0012]). 11. Harvest seeds from a single plant at a time by cutting off the base of the plant at the soil level using a pair of scissors while keeping the 4-in. twist tie in place to prevent the loss of any seed that has already shattered from the dry inflorescence (Fig. 13A[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0013] and 13B[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0013]).

imgsrc:https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/cms/asset/ead8774d-00fa-4b90-b9a1-edbe78b7af43/cpz1127-fig-0013-m.jpg

Figure 13 Seed drying and harvest. (A) Dry inflorescence inside the bag. (B) Close-up view of the mature and dried inflorescence. (C) Close-up view of harvested mature dry seeds. 12. Invert the bag containing the plant so that all seed will fall toward the “top” of the bag, and tap the panicles to dislodge the remaining mature seed.

13. Using scissors, snip off a corner of the bag and transfer seeds into a clean weighing boat.
14. Clean the seeds from any plant debris and transfer clean seeds into small coin envelope (Fig. 13C[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-fig-0013]). Label the packet and store at 4°C.
Molecular analysis of putative transgenic events can be performed using the DNA isolated from the tissues samples collected from tissue culture materials or greenhouse grown plants following the standard PCR or TAQMAN® assay described by Van Eck, Swartwood, Pidgeon, and Maxson-Stein (2017[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-bib-0020]).

In this Support Protocol[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-prot-0004], we describe the initiation of master plate from Agrobacterium strain AGL1 harboring a binary plasmid with a gene of interest stored in a −80°C freezer.
Materials
Agrobacterium glycerol stock AGL1 containing pANIC10A (pANIC10A plasmid obtained from Addgene). Note that the pANIC10A binary vector is selected due to the presence of a ubiquitin-driven hygromycin phosphotransferase (hyg) cassette as a selectable marker.
LB medium plates with appropriate antibiotics (see recipe[href=https://currentprotocols.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/cpz1.127#cpz1127-rec-0005])
Sterile loop (VWR, cat. no. 30002-090)
Aluminum foil
Permanent marker
Gloves
−80°C freezer
28°C incubator
1. A. tumefaciens strain AGL1 containing the binary vector (pANIC10A) is stored as a glycerol stock at −80°C.
2. As needed, and at least every 3-4 weeks, a “master” plate can be re-initiated from this glycerol stock by streaking the bacteria on LB medium plates with appropriate antibiotics and incubating for 2 days at 28°C.
3. The “master” plate can be stored up to 4 weeks at 4°C and used as a source plate for initiating a fresh Agrobacteria culture, 3 days prior to transformation experiments.
